abstract: <jats:p>In a recent genome‐wide association study (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWAS</jats:styled-content>) from an international consortium, evidence of linkage and association in chr8q24 was much stronger among nonsyndromic cleft lip/palate (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CL</jats:styled-content>/<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>) case‐parent trios of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry than among trios of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian ancestry. We examined marker information content and haplotype diversity across 13 recruitment sites (from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>urope, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">U</jats:styled-content>nited <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>tates, and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sia) separately, and conducted principal components analysis (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PCA</jats:styled-content>) on parents. As expected, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PCA</jats:styled-content> revealed large genetic distances between <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropeans and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sians, and a north‐south cline from <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">K</jats:styled-content>orea to <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>ingapore in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sia, with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">F</jats:styled-content>ilipino parents forming a somewhat distinct <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>outheast <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian cluster. Hierarchical clustering of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> heterozygosity revealed two major clades consistent with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PCA</jats:styled-content> results. All genotyped <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s giving <jats:italic>P</jats:italic> < 10<jats:sup>−6</jats:sup> in the allelic transmission disequilibrium test (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">TDT</jats:styled-content>) showed higher heterozygosity in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropeans than <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sians. On average, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropean ancestry parents had higher haplotype diversity than <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sians. Imputing additional variants across chr8q24 increased the strength of statistical evidence among <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">E</jats:styled-content>uropeans and also revealed a significant signal among <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sians (although it did not reach genome‐wide significance). Tests for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>‐population interaction were negative, indicating the lack of strong signal for 8q24 in families of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sian ancestry was not due to any distinct genetic effect, but could simply reflect low power due to lower allele frequencies in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>sians. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:392–399, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

title: Examining Markers in 8q24 to Explain Differences in Evidence for Association With Cleft Lip With/Without Cleft Palate Between <scp>A</scp>sians and <scp>E</scp>uropeans
